repnme.cdata!:
Lithuania - Klaipeda Port Project, and
            Poland - Szczecin-Swinoujscie Seaway and Port Modernization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Klaipeda Port Project
            for Lithuania are as follows: outcome was moderately
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was moderate, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Ratings for the
            Szczecin-Swinoujscie Seaway and Port Modernization Project
            for Poland are as follows: outcome was moderately
            unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was moderate,
            Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Both ports have
            increased their competitiveness by combination of major
            rehabilitation of their marine facilities with
            transformation, more radical than foreseen in the
            Bank's forecasts, in the structure of their traffic.
            Klaipeda responded effectively to unexpected loss of much of
            its transit trade by converting many of its facilities to
            better meet the needs of other traffics, national and
            transit, and has become mainly a national port.
            Szczecin-Swinoujscie was equally called upon to cope with
            significantly larger than expected reduction in its
            traditional traffics, and it achieved a very rapid growth of
            new and more profitable container and ferry traffics despite
            links with its hinterland much weaker than in the case of
            Lithuania, due to their different histories in the last few
            decades. A vital task of ports is to ascertain the changing
            hinterland, or geographic market area, that they can expect
            to serve, and to identify and help resolve policy or
            infrastructure obstacles to the development of new trades.
            It should now be normal to have an economist experienced in
            trade and transport issues participate in a supervision
            mission to a port borrower at least once every twelve or
            eighteen months. Probably the most significant lesson with
            regard specifically to ports that emerges from the
            experience of these two projects is to underline the
            importance of port efforts to lead identification of its
            potential hinterland, stimulate private initiatives to help
            bring the hinterland's trades to life, and work with
            government ministries and services to overcome bureaucratic
            and policy obstacles.

repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Szczecin-Swinoujscie Seaway and
            Port Modernization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Szczecin-Swinoujscie
            Seaway and Port Modernization Project for Poland were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: changing
            external economic, politic, institutional, legal and social
            circumstances could end up diluting the relevance of the
            development objectives, or place them at cross-purposes with
            real life developments. Turnover of key staff on the
            Borrower's side, including major stakeholders, can
            undermine the project's success, and lead to a loss of
            continuity. If the Bank is going to finance facilities which
            are intended for public-private partnerships, such as a
            container terminal, it should try and be certain that the
            capacity exists in the Government to carry it out. If the
            capacity does not exist, the Loan should finance technical
            assistance for that purpose.

repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Szczecin-Swinoujscie Seaway and
            Port Modernization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Szczecin-Swinoujscie Seaway and Port
            Modernization Project aims to promote Poland's trade by
            developing an efficient administrative/managerial structure
            and improving physical facilities in the main ports of
            Gdansk, Gdynia, and Szczecin-Swinoujscie. The project has
            four components. 1) Physical Modernization of
            Szczecin-Swinoujscie Seaway will include strengthening the
            banks of parts of the channel over a total length of 2,600
            meters on both sides, rebuilding intermediate breakwaters,
            establishing containment areas for dredged materials in the
            vicinity of Szczecin, and providing technical assistance to
            define and implement environmentally sound dredging methods.
            2) Maritime Office Szczecin (MOS) Technical Assistance and
            Training will provide for technical assistance and training
            to help MOS define and implement environmentally sound
            dredging methods. 3) Szczecin-Swinoujscie Seaport Authority:
            Katowice Peninsula will include land preparation and
            construction of berthing facilities to provide additional
            operational space to be leased out to private enterprises
            and operators, for cargo handling, storage, and packaging
            facilities, mainly for industrial bulks. 4)
            Szczcin-Swinoujscie Seaport Authority: Grabowski Island will
            include land preparation and construction of berthing
            facilities to provide additional operational space to be
            leased out to private enterprises and operators.

Poland - Szczecin-Swinoujscie Seaway and
            Port Modernization Project

repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Port Modernization Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Environmental Assessment (EA)
            forecasts the potential negative effects on the natural
            environment, resulting from the construction works related
            to the Port Modernization Project, and determines mitigating
            measures for navigational conditions, hydraulics,
            environmental pollution, and assets - specifically, the
            fishing industry's aquatic bio-system environmental
            conditions. On the basis of the selection criteria, the
            approach to be taken regarding the construction of the sea
            waterway, would be a hydro-technical development, with
            specified depths for navigational canals. This in turn will
            require the construction of a new breakwater system at the
            entrance to the Piastowski Canal from the Szczecin Lagoon,
            to improve water flows, and allow natural removal of
            depressions. Concerning the modernization of the port
            infrastructure, mitigation measures include stationary
            monitoring posts, and monitoring ships, to conduct
            environmental tests regarding land, water, and air
            pollution. Strict monitoring will control the aquatic
            environment against degradation, due to effluent flows from
            land dredging spoil deposits, to be undertaken by the
            Environmental Protection Inspectorate, and Port Authority.
            Specialized laboratories in Szczecin will conduct sanitary,
            and epidemiological tests on water, and bedrock conditions.

display_title.display_title:
Poland - Port Modernization
            Project : environmental assessment : Summary report
